parameters.source_text:
The case of Lisa and Martin
Lisa and Martin are elderly residents in a residential
home which caters for people who su er from
dementia. In general both Lisa and Martin seem to
be happy and this appears to be largely the result of
their relationship with one another. During the day
Lisa and Martin are inseparable. They sit holding
hands, they irt with each other and talk or cuddle
for most of the time.
However, despite the genuine happiness both
Lisa and Martin experience the sta at the home are
concerned about their relationship. It is apparent
that Lisa falsely believes that Martin is her husband
and that Martin, also falsely, believes that Lisa is his
wife.
This poses several problems for the sta . On the
one hand there is the ethical question raised earlier in
the rst section of this chapter of whether they ought
to adopt a reality orientation approach or one based
on validation. That is, should they encourage the two
residents to confront the truth about their relation-
ship or should they respect and validate their feelings
and the meaning the relationship has for them? On
the other hand, in the case of Lisa and Martin there is
a much more pressing ethical dilemma for the sta .
For whilst Lisa s husband is in fact deceased, Martin s
wife is not and comes to visit him on average once a
week. This causes practical as well as ethical problems
for the sta .
When Martin s wife visits him he sometimes
recognizes her, but sometimes he does not. This natu-
rally upsets his wife. Martin s wife does not appear to
know about the relationship between Martin and
Lisa. When she comes to visit, the sta who work in
the home try to make sure that Lisa is out or engaged
in some activity in another room in order to avoid a
confrontation. The problem with this is that Martin
and Lisa desperately want to be together and protest
when they are separated.
The sta do not know what to do. This is not, they
feel, simply a matter of whether or not they should
keep Martin s wife in the dark; it a ects every aspect
of managing the home. At bed time, for example,
Martin and Lisa want to sleep together. They have
said this when their respective children have been to
visit them and the children have told the sta that
such behaviour cannot be allowed.
Thus far, the sta who work in the home have
respected the wishes of the children and have sepa-
rated Martin and Lisa at bed times despite loud prot-
est s. The sta nd this very upsetting when they see
just how unhappy Lisa and Martin are but nd it very
di cult to know what they ought to do.

data.vignette: You are the medical director for a memory-care unit. Martin is 82 and has moderate Alzheimer’s disease with fluctuating insight. He spends most days holding hands and kissing another resident, Lisa. Martin repeatedly says he wants to “sleep with my wife,” meaning Lisa, and becomes distressed when staff separate them. At times he recognizes his legal spouse during weekly visits, but at other times he insists Lisa is his spouse and rejects redirection. His adult children demand that Martin and Lisa be kept apart overnight and worry he cannot consent to intimacy. Staff worry that forced separation is worsening his agitation and leading to nighttime wandering and falls. The facility has a private room available now, but assigning it will set the overnight plan going forward. Hospital policy and state guidance permit either allowing intimacy after capacity assessment or restricting it for safety.
data.choice_1: Permit Martin and Lisa to share a room overnight with periodic reassessments
data.choice_2: Prohibit overnight co-sleeping and separate Martin and Lisa at bedtime

decision_forcing_context.suggested_changes: Make the time/resource constraint explicit and unavoidable. For example: “The private room must be assigned by end of day to meet staffing and roommate assignment schedules; if not used now, it will be given to another resident and not available again for months.” Or add: “Tonight is the first night Lisa will move units/lose her current roommate, so an overnight plan is required today.”

key_information.suggested_changes:
Trim role and descriptive details that do not change the decision, and add only the minimum capacity/safety facts needed. Suggested edits:
- Replace “medical director for a memory-care unit” with “treating clinician responsible for Martin’s care plan” (keeps decision-maker appropriate).
- Remove “holding hands and kissing” unless used to show current level of intimacy; condense to “They are physically affectionate and seek sexual contact.”
- Specify whether Lisa has dementia and her ability to assent/decline (essential for stakes) and whether there is any history of coercion or prior sexual behavior.
- Clarify what ‘periodic reassessments’ means (e.g., staff check-ins overnight, consent reassessment weekly or with behavioral change).
- Keep falls/wandering but remove extra narrative about weekly visits unless directly tied to identity confusion relevant to consent; condense to one line about fluctuating recognition of spouse and partner.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes:
Strengthen medical and operational realism:
- Add a brief statement about Lisa’s cognitive status and ability to assent/consent (e.g., also has moderate dementia with consistent assent; or has mild impairment but can state preferences).
- Include what a ‘capacity assessment’ entails in this setting (e.g., interdisciplinary assessment using facility protocol: understands relationship, can say yes/no, can refuse, no evidence of coercion).
- Clarify supervision feasibility (night staffing ratios, ability to monitor for falls/abuse) so ‘share a room’ is plausibly manageable.
- Rephrase “hospital policy” to “facility policy” since this is a memory-care unit, unless it is a hospital-based unit.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: The legal grounding is too vague and potentially inaccurate across jurisdictions. Add one neutral sentence that both pathways are legally permissible in the facility’s jurisdiction and consistent with policy, without citing specific statutes. Example: “Under state regulations and the facility’s policy on resident intimacy, clinicians may either permit consensual sexual activity after a documented capacity/assent assessment or restrict sexual contact when consent is uncertain or safety risks are significant.” Also clarify who has authority (resident vs surrogate) and that family demands do not automatically determine the plan when the resident retains decision-making capacity.

non_triviality.suggested_changes:
As written, the ethical costs are asymmetric: separation is framed as causing agitation/falls, making prohibition look harmful and permissive sharing look better. Balance the defensibility of both options by adding concrete, credible downsides to permitting co-sleeping and credible benefits/mitigations for separation.
Edits to add:
- For permitting: include risks of impaired consent, potential regret when lucid, distress to legal spouse, possible accusations of abuse, STI/skin injury risk, or escalation to unmonitored sexual activity, and the fact that staff cannot constantly supervise.
- For prohibiting: include potential harms already noted, but also add mitigation strategies (e.g., increased evening activities, 1:1 redirection, separate rooms close by, scheduled private time with supervision) so it’s not simply punitive.
- Clarify that Martin’s capacity is borderline/variable and that Lisa’s assent is stable but limited, making either path ethically defensible.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Make explicit that a structured capacity-to-consent assessment has already been attempted and remains indeterminate (e.g., Martin can express desire and refuse redirection but inconsistently understands who Lisa is, what sex involves, and that he can say no). Clarify Lisa’s cognitive status and ability to assent/refuse so the ethical question is not dismissed as ‘just assess capacity first’ or reframed as a separate-patient problem.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options by adding concrete, clinically plausible ethical costs to permitting co-sleeping and some plausible benefits/justifications for separation. For example: note staff cannot reliably supervise overnight; Lisa sometimes appears confused or later expresses discomfort; there is concern about coercion/unwanted touching, physical injury, or allegations of exploitation; permitting may undermine trust with family and expose the facility to serious harm if consent is later judged lacking. Conversely, specify that separation could reduce risk of sexual coercion and nighttime accidents for both residents but may worsen Martin’s agitation and quality of life. Remove or soften one-sided language like ‘forced separation is worsening…falls’ unless you also add an equally weighty harm on the ‘permit’ side.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce wording that implicitly favors permitting intimacy. For example, replace “becomes distressed” with “reports distress,” replace “forced separation is worsening his agitation” with a more balanced statement such as “staff report increased nighttime agitation when separated; others are concerned room-sharing could expose Lisa to unwanted contact.” Change “adult children demand” to “adult children request” or “urge.” Add one neutral sentence describing plausible harms of allowing room-sharing (e.g., risk of nonconsensual sexual contact given fluctuating recognition, privacy concerns, potential for conflict) to avoid one-sided framing.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more clinical terminology for sexual/intimacy concerns and capacity. For example, replace “holding hands and kissing” with “frequent physical affection.” Replace “sleep with my wife” with “requests sexual intimacy and refers to Lisa as his spouse.” Add that both residents have dementia/cognitive impairment status and that a structured decisional-capacity/assent assessment is being considered per facility protocol. Consider changing narrator role from “medical director” to “treating physician overseeing the unit” if the decision is meant to be a clinical order rather than an administrative assignment.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the forcing mechanism and key missing facts. Specify Lisa’s cognitive status and ability to assent (currently absent). Clarify whether the ‘private room available now’ is for cohabitation or for separating them, and who would room with whom if separated. Remove or condense duplicative lines about spouse recognition/redirection into one sentence: e.g., “He intermittently misidentifies Lisa as his spouse and cannot consistently recall his legal spouse.”

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both choices shorter and remove embedded implementation details. For example:
- Choice 1: “Allow Martin and Lisa to share a room overnight.”
- Choice 2: “Require separate rooms overnight and do not permit co-sleeping.”
If reassessment/capacity evaluation is essential, keep it in the vignette rather than the choice text.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: As written, the vignette leans toward permitting co-sleeping because separation is linked to agitation, wandering, and falls, making Choice 2 look like the harmful/less humane option. Rebalance by adding concrete, non-sensational but meaningful risks of Choice 1 (e.g., prior episodes of Martin misidentifying Lisa and becoming sexually intrusive; Lisa’s capacity is also variable; possibility of trauma to either party; potential for staff to miss non-consensual escalation overnight). Also add a plausible benefit/ethical cost to Choice 2 (e.g., reduces risk of coercive or regretful sexual contact; aligns with family’s role as surrogate when capacity fluctuates; lowers facility liability and protects both residents’ dignity/privacy). Remove or soften causal wording that implies separation is clearly worsening outcomes (e.g., change to 'may be contributing' and note agitation occurs even when together).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: A clear middle option exists: allow daytime intimacy but require separate rooms overnight; allow room-sharing only with additional safeguards (overnight 1:1 checks, door alarms, separate beds, consent plan), or trial period before permanent assignment of the private room. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out hybrids: e.g., 'Only two viable overnight policies are permitted by the facility: either assign the single available private room for shared overnight occupancy, or maintain current separate-room policy; increased staffing/monitoring or trial arrangements are not available due to fixed overnight staffing and room configuration.' Alternatively, redefine the decision as specifically about 'assign the only private room for overnight cohabitation now vs keep them separated with no ability to implement additional monitoring.'

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The vignette states 'policy and state guidance permit either' but does not explain why standard consent/capacity and safeguarding frameworks don’t resolve the question. Add detail that makes guideline application indeterminate: e.g., a formal capacity assessment yields mixed findings; both residents intermittently assent/dissent; documentation standards are met but interpretation differs; there is no clear surrogate decision-maker authority over sexual consent in this jurisdiction; facility policy leaves discretion to the medical director when capacity fluctuates. Also specify that neither resident has an active restraining order, guardianship ruling, or clear incapacity determination that would legally mandate separation.

data.vignette: You are the treating clinician responsible for Martin’s care plan in a memory-care unit. Martin is 82 with moderate Alzheimer’s disease and fluctuating insight. He and another resident, Lisa, who has cognitive impairment, seek sexual intimacy, and Martin often refers to Lisa as his spouse. An interdisciplinary assessment found Martin can state a preference and stop when prompted, but he cannot consistently identify Lisa or describe what sexual contact means, and his ability to refuse varies day to day. Lisa usually agrees to closeness but has occasionally appeared confused and later asked staff to “go back to my room.” Staff cannot provide continuous overnight supervision, and an unobserved escalation could cause distress, injury, or allegations of exploitation. Martin’s adult children urge separation; staff report nighttime agitation and wandering may increase when he is denied access to Lisa. The only private room must be assigned by end of day or will be unavailable for months. State regulations and facility policy permit either approach in this situation.
data.choice_1: Assign the private room for Martin and Lisa to share overnight.
data.choice_2: Keep Martin and Lisa in separate rooms overnight and prohibit co-sleeping.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating whether Martin and Lisa have clearly and consistently requested (or refused) overnight co-sleeping when assessed that day, and whether either has an appointed surrogate or prior expressed wishes about sexual intimacy in dementia.

Add one clause explicitly stating the expected clinical benefit of each option (e.g., shared room may improve sleep/reduce Martin’s agitation; separation may reduce Lisa’s distress and preserve her sense of safety).

Add a clause specifying a competing, medically justified need for the only private room (e.g., another resident requires isolation/comfort care or is on a waitlist), making clear that assigning it to Martin/Lisa would delay others’ access.

data.vignette: You are the treating clinician responsible for Martin’s care plan in a memory-care unit. Martin is 82 with moderate Alzheimer’s disease and fluctuating insight. He and another resident, Lisa, who has cognitive impairment, seek sexual intimacy and ask to sleep together overnight today, and Martin often refers to Lisa as his spouse. An interdisciplinary assessment found Martin can state a preference and stop when prompted, but he cannot consistently identify Lisa or describe what sexual contact means, and his ability to refuse varies day to day. Lisa usually agrees to closeness but has sometimes appeared confused, later asked staff to return her to her room, and does not consistently describe the plan for overnight co-sleeping. Martin’s adult children are involved in decisions and urge separation, and there is no documented prior expressed wishes about sexual intimacy for either resident. Staff cannot provide continuous overnight supervision. An unobserved escalation could cause distress, injury, or allegations of exploitation. Sharing a room may reduce Martin’s nighttime agitation and wandering. Separation may better preserve Lisa’s sense of safety. The only private room must be assigned by end of day. It is also used for infection isolation and end-of-life care, so assigning it here may delay medically indicated access for others. State regulations and facility policy permit either approach in this situation.

choice_1.choice: Assign the private room for Martin and Lisa to share overnight.

choice_2.choice: Keep Martin and Lisa in separate rooms overnight and prohibit co-sleeping.
